newsitem.title: PERU: Peru plans sale of minority stakes in sugar mills.
newsitem.headline: Peru plans sale of minority stakes in sugar mills.

text.p: The Peruvian government plans to sell off minority stakes in 20 sugar mills, completing their transformation from Soviet-style cooperatives to private enterprises, an official resolution said Friday.

The resolution, published in the official gazette El Peruano, said the government acquired shares in the firms in exchange for debts the companies accumulated during more than 25 years as communist cooperatives.
The resolution said investment in the firms will be possible after capital injections to ensure the sector's rehabilitation.
The state's holding varies by mill depending on how much debt was swapped.
The government began transforming the ailing sugar industry in 1996 by instituting a program for the cooperatives to become private enterprises where workers and investors could own shares.
The move was intended to halt a dramatic slide in sugar production that began in the 1970s.

Until 1969, Peru was a sugar exporter, producing some 992,464 tonnes of sugar a year. But annual output has fallen steadily in the last two decades to about 600,000 tonnes in recent years, and local production has not been enough to cover national demand of some 900,000 tonnes a year.
According to the Agriculture Ministry, the state's sugar cooperatives accumulated debts of up to $185 million and require some $340 million in investment to revamp its operating capacity.
